title: Forfeiture reform aligns conservative, liberal groups
text:
Charles Koch, ACLU want states to overhaul civil asset forfeiture policies Vikrant Reddy, right, a senior researcher at the Charles Koch Institute speaks during a forum about civil asset forfeiture with Albuquerque, N.M., attorney Diego Esquibel at Hotel Albuquerque on Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. (AP Photo/Mary Hudetz)
Associated Press Oct. 15, 2015 | 2:22 a.m. EDT + More By MARY HUDETZ, Associated Press
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) â€” An unlikely pair of allies wants more states to restrict civil asset forfeiture, a practice critics say represents an overused law enforcement tactic that can violate citizens' property rights.
The Charles Koch Institute, named for the wealthy conservative founder of the Washington, D.C.-area think tank, co-hosted a forum on the topic Wednesday evening in Albuquerque joined by the state director of the American Civil Liberties Union.
They say New Mexico offers a model for civil forfeiture reform with a law enacted in July that prevents police from seizing money or assets unless a person is convicted of a crime.
Before, law enforcement could seize items and auction them off if they suspected they were linked to a crime.
Law enforcement officers who support civil asset forfeiture say it's needed to weaken lucrative crime operations.
